articles.headline: Automakers Change Course on Fuel Standards
articles.snippet: A behind-the-scenes battle in Congress over fuel economy standards has ended with automakers cheering the rules.
articles.abstract: A behind-the-scenes battle in Congress over fuel economy standards has ended with automakers cheering the rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Just six months ago, an auto industry trade group warned that consumers could be forced to buy vehicles they did not want if Congress went too far in raising fuel economy standards.

articles.headline: Web Access and E-Mail on Flights
articles.snippet: Starting next week and over the next few months, several United States airlines will test Internet service on their planes.
articles.abstract: Starting next week and over the next few months, several United States airlines will test Internet service on their planes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Passengers may soon hear a new in-flight announcement: “You can now log on.”

articles.headline: U.S. Agency’s Slow Pace Endangers Foreign Aid
articles.snippet: The Millennium Challenge Corporation has taken longer than expected to help poor, well-governed countries.
articles.abstract: The Millennium Challenge Corporation has taken longer than expected to help poor, well-governed countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Millennium Challenge Corporation, a federal agency set up almost four years ago to reinvent foreign aid, has taken far longer to help poor, well-governed countries than its supporters expected or its critics say is reasonable.

articles.headline: Murdoch Said to Have Plan for Shake-Up at Dow Jones
articles.snippet: The departure of Richard F. Zannino, Dow Jones’s chief executive, was announced Thursday, a week before News Corporation is expected to take control of the company.
articles.abstract: The departure of Richard F. Zannino, Dow Jones’s chief executive, was announced Thursday, a week before News Corporation is expected to take control of the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: With a week to go before the News Corporation takes control of Dow Jones & Company, there are already management changes under way at the top of Dow Jones.

articles.headline: A New Bush Tack on North Korea
articles.snippet: The president wrote a letter to Kim Jong-il, his first direct communication with the reclusive North Korean dictator.
articles.abstract: The president wrote a letter to Kim Jong-il, his first direct communication with the reclusive North Korean dictator.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  President Bush, directly engaging the man he publicly called a “tyrant,” wrote a letter to North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-il, in which he held out the prospect of normalized relations with the United States if North Korea fully disclosed its nuclear programs and dismantled its nuclear reactor, administration officials said Thursday.

articles.headline: Romney, Eye on Evangelicals, Defends His Faith
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney said “Mormon” only once in his speech, underscoring how touchy the issue of his faith has been.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney said “Mormon” only once in his speech, underscoring how touchy the issue of his faith has been.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Dec. 6  Mitt Romney asked the nation on Thursday not to reject his presidential candidacy because of his religion, assuring evangelical Christians and other religious voters that his values matched theirs in a speech that used the word “Mormon” only once.

articles.headline: When a Public Offering Goes Bad Down Under
articles.snippet: A failed I.P.O. in the Australian mortgage industry may offer some lessons for the American market.
articles.abstract: A failed I.P.O. in the Australian mortgage industry may offer some lessons for the American market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The founder of the company took in more than half a billion dollars by selling most of his stock to the public. Three weeks later, the company fell apart.

articles.headline: Former Chief Will Forfeit $418 Million
articles.snippet: The founder of UnitedHealth Group, William W. McGuire, reached a settlement with regulators over the backdating of stock options and will forfeit $418 million in options and retirement benefits.
articles.abstract: The founder of UnitedHealth Group, William W. McGuire, reached a settlement with regulators over the backdating of stock options and will forfeit $418 million in options and retirement benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: In one of the largest corporate pay give-backs ever, William W. McGuire, the former chief executive of UnitedHealth Group, has agreed to forfeit at least $418 million to settle claims related to back-dated stock options.

articles.headline: In Mortgage Plan, Lenders Set Terms
articles.snippet: Bush’s plan to help people trapped by the mortgage meltdown is industry-led, not a government bailout.
articles.abstract: Bush’s plan to help people trapped by the mortgage meltdown is industry-led, not a government bailout.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  At least one thing is clear about President Bush’s plan to help people trapped by the mortgage meltdown: it is an industry-led plan, not a government bailout.
